<!-- English -->

::: {.content-visible when-profile="en"}
# Professional and Academic Focus 


::: justified
I've delved into diverse knowledge areas throughout my professional career, shaping my perspective. Below, I outline key areas that have captured my attention, with references to my own contributions where relevant.
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Academia-Industry Collaboration (AIC)
<details>
<summary> ★ **Building bridges to increase the impact of ideas**   </summary>

::: justified
<br>
The transfer of knowledge between academic and business organizations to promote innovation is the main subject I have been working on for the last 5 or 6 years. So far it has been a process which involved navigating multiple perspectives, continuously increasing in its complexity.


My PhD Thesis, titled "Understanding Knowledge Dynamics Across Modes of Academia-Industry Collaboration:
A Comprehensive Mixed-Method Analysis within the I-Space Framework: Lessons from San Carlos de Bariloche, Argentina", represent the last and most profound stage of this process.

:::

</details>

### Knowledge Management and Organizational Learning
<details>
<summary> **Designing strategies for the collective production of knowledge**  </summary>

::: justified
<br>
A critical topic I studied for my doctorate and which I now implement in my day to day. 

* It is worth mentioning the theoretical framework developed by Boisot [-@boisot1995] for understanding information and knowledge flows in social settings: the *Information Space* or *I-Space*. In my [**blog**](blog.qmd), I am now trying to synthesize and use this framework to analyze the conjuncture.

:::
</details>

### Economics, Institutions, and Culture
<details>

<summary> **Exploring the socio-cultural foundations of economic and human behavior**  </summary>

::: justified
<br>
How culture and institutional arrangements define the management of resources, information, and knowledge? 

* Besides exploring Academia-Industry Collaborations, with another classmate of the master we made an analysis of hackerspace and makerspaces based on Ostrom's [-@ostrom1990] idea of commons.

* Beyond my limited contribution to the subject, a few approaches worth mentioning are innovation systems [@cooke2001; @etzkowitz2000; @lundvall1988; @nelson1993], open innovation [@chesbrough2003; @vonhippel2005], commons [@allen2016; @hess2007; @kostakis2015; @ostrom1990], and information economics [@boisot1998].

:::

</details>

### Platforms and Digitalization
<details>
<summary> **Navigating the Digital Age**  </summary>

::: justified
<br>
The continuous proliferation of information and communication technologies (ICTs) has a strong impact on the production of knowledge and information.

* With my PhD supervisor we've broadly explored the [foundations of digital platforms and their classification](https://comein.uoc.edu/divulgacio/oikonomics/_recursos/documents/14/canals-hulskamp_Oikonomics14_esp.pdf).

* I'm particularly drawn to theoretical perspectives like Gawer [-@gawer2020]. I believe understanding how these platforms are reshaping economic and social interactions is fundamental. 

:::

</details>

### Graph Theory and Network Analysis
<details>
<summary> **Unraveling relationships beyond the actors** </summary>
::: justified
<br>
Representing complexity as interconnected and interdependent systems, considering both nodes and the links that connect them [@b枚rner2007; @granovetter1973; @granovetter1983; @newman2018]. 

* I have worked with bibliometric databases and survey data to analyze collaboration processes among researchers and between academic and business stakeholders. [**Here**](visualMedia/hulskampPresentation.mp4) you can see my presentation "Scientific Collaboration through Institutional Networks: The Value of National Partners" at the [NetSci 2021](https://networks2021.net/) conference.

:::
</details>

### Philosophy: Pragmatism, Enactivism, Education, Psychology
<details>
<summary> **Philosophy in action**  </summary>
::: justified
<br>
I have explored pragmatism and enactivists approaches [e.g., @dewey1923; @varela2017], as well as their application in fields like education and psychology [e.g., @bereiter2014; @kress2009; @scardamalia2010].

* As part of my undergraduate thesis and as a research fellow at CIECE, I researched how economic models typically fail to successfully represent complexity.  
:::

</details>

### Complexity Theory and Information Theory
<details>
<summary>З **Exploring the complexity of phenomena** </summary>

::: justified
<br>
Enthusiasm for emergent properties, entropy [@ben-naim2008], the groundbreaking work of Claude Shannon [-@shannon1949], and subsequent studies in various knowledge areas [e.g., @boisot2004; @gleick2011; @snowden2002; @polyanskiy2022]. I recently participated in an interesting [course](https://www.youtube.com/@redcompleja4990) on complex networks.
